>> Ok, but this doesn't address why they need to invent an
>> entirely separate cache-control mechanism, instead of 
>> reusing and extending what we already have around HTTP.
>>
>> The stale-if-error directive introduced by the Cache-Control
>> Extensions for Stale Content[1] already gives us most of
>> what they are trying to achieve.
>
> *Boom*, that's exactly my point.

It's different I would say. The app cache is really for applications. You
include all your app assets and code and then "install" it. It doesn't make
that much sense to have parts with different lifetimes in such a scenario
and the manifest is more or less just a way to create a package. It also
gives you APIs to check the state of your cache and so on..

How else would you achieve that in a browser? Since the browser doesn't know
what belongs together it would probably delete a huge JS file at some point
while still keeping the other stuff. This would break your app. So perhaps
think of it more in terms of an app than in terms of caching.



--
Markus Lanthaler
